body:

title: APP CITY; Christmas in the City, Beyond That Tree

Rebekah Carver, Brooklyn Hearth Realty (646) 489-4446; brooklynhearth.com
title: On The Market

body:
‘THE GRINCH’S 

 
HOLIDAY WORKSHOP’
 Although it may seem sacrilegious to criticize Dr. Seuss , his book title “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” is a misnomer. The Grinch’s plot doesn’t succeed because the holiday can’t be stolen, at least not in Who-ville, where Christmas
title: Spare Times: For Children

body:
After I quit running a few months ago because of knee pain , I figured that my days of high-impact workouts were over. And they were, until I stumbled upon a pair of bouncy, spring-loaded shoes designed for running and jumping without offending the joints. 
 
These rebound shoes, called Kangoo Jumps , arrived in New York City when the
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Putting the Bounce Back in Your Step

body:
RISING demand and a scarcity of new apartments are creating something of a rush on new luxury condominiums in choice New York neighborhoods, with buyers increasingly signing contracts for spaces even before they are built.
 
Last month sales opened for 200 East 79th Street , a Skyline Developers project. The building is still going up, but
title: The Take-It-on-Faith Condo

body: WHEN Charles Lockwood’s now-classic book “Bricks and Brownstones” was published in the early ‘70s, there was only one thing to do with an old New York town house — restore it to within an inch of its pristine 19th-century glory. The brownstone revival movement had started a few years earlier, and in Manhattan and
title: The Revisionists

body:
Benefits for Storm Relief

 
Last year, Meat Week was organized to help farmers in the Hudson Valley recover from Tropical Storm Irene. This year’s Meat Week, through  Sunday, will help the Rockaways, which were devastated by Hurricane Sandy . There will be a benefit tasting of meat-centric food on Thursday from 6:30 to 9:30
title: Calendar

body:
Opening

 
DELMONICO’S KITCHEN It has been 175 years since Delmonico’s opened in the financial district, and its first satellite, in Midtown, is meant to be a prototype for a worldwide expansion. It’s also a note of optimism for Delmonico’s, whose flagship was badly flooded last week but will reopen Friday.
title: Off the Menu

body: When Hurricane Sandy sent water tearing into Tony Locane ’s basement last week, he rushed down the stairs to save what he could — his computer, a few pieces of his artwork — as the water climbed up the walls and up his legs from one foot to two feet, to three and to four. And when he retreated to the safety of higher ground, he
title: THE APPRAISAL; In Brooklyn, Worrying About Not Only Flooding But Also What’s in Water

body:
IT is a sliver of a word, and a nonspecific one at that, but in New York City real estate, “prewar” speaks volumes. 
 
The term, applied generally to apartment buildings built before World War II, conjures images of high ceilings, thick walls, plaster ornamentation and generous layouts. That much, most New Yorkers who have
title: GETTING STARTED; Postwar, Prewar and Everything Before

body: FOR four years, since shortly before their marriage, Kristina Frantz and Pierre Alexandre lived in a spacious three-bedroom duplex in a two-family house in Carroll Gardens. title: THE HUNT; A Tall Order

body: Carroll Gardens can remember a time decades ago when its southern edge was not the fetching brownstone- and row-house-rich magnet it has become for young strivers and couples with children -- a time when the neighborhood was studded with vacant buildings. That is why much of the generally politically liberal Brooklyn neighborhood has been seething
title: Sharp Reaction to Plan For Shelter in Brooklyn

body: Opening ANTICA PESA WILLIAMSBURG Francesco and Simone Panella, who own Antica Pesa in the Trastevere district of Rome, are trying their hand at New York. They see Williamburg, Brooklyn, as comparable to Trastevere, which is also artsy and across a river from the central city. Their menu is dominated by Roman classics, including spaghetti cacio e

They represent an emphatic confirmation of what local artists and other urban pioneers have increasingly feared -- that real estate operators would officially
title: Grand Plan for a Toxic Site Is Scorned and Celebrated

body: EVEN within the rarefied region of brownstone Brooklyn , where landmark protections abound and residents speak of vintage cornices in the same knowing manner they discuss artisanal cheeses, the low-rise streetscape of Cobble Hill is distinctive for its consistently intimate 19th-century feel. At the neighborhood's heart, the serene green wedge of
title: LIVING IN | COBBLE HILL, BROOKLYN; Land of the Multi-No-Longer Family House

body: 7:30 P.M. (Showtime) I DON'T KNOW HOW SHE DOES IT (2011) Sarah Jessica Parker portrays Kate Reddy, a hotshot manager for a Boston investment company and multitasker par excellence who suddenly finds herself unable to have it all. Greg Kinnear (above, with Ms. Parker) is her long-suffering husband, Richard, a struggling architect, who is left to
title: What's On Today

body: There are some New Yorkers for whom the word ''bus'' can conjure unpleasant memories of long delays. Or perhaps an unpleasant sojourn in the bowels of the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Or maybe in a less ominous connotation, simply a poor alternative to the subway. Those New Yorkers were in short supply in Downtown Brooklyn on Sunday, where a block
title: A Love for Public Transit Of the Aboveground Variety

body: THE MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL Puff is already taken. Sparky or Flash might be cute. Or how about Vulcan? It has a weighty, mythological resonance. Oh, never mind. I'm way too old to enter the Medieval Festival's Name That Dragon contest. But children 6 to 12 can submit their own suggestions on Sunday in Fort Tryon Park, where the dragon, above, designed by
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: A man was fatally shot by a New York City police officer late Thursday night in Brooklyn, the police said. The police did not immediately provide details about what led to the shooting, but did say that three people were taken into custody and that a gun was recovered at the scene. An officer was treated for a minor injury, although the police
title: Man Fatally Shot by Officer in Brooklyn

author: Dan Klores is a Peabody Award-winning filmmaker and playwright. His first film was ''The Boys of Second Street Park.''
body: Before I was to play in the public school gym or the local Y, and at about the same time I had my first crush on Annette, the Mouseketeer , I used to gaze at the tall, gray steel backboard with the orange rim. For my first shot, I used a dodgeball. I didn't have, let alone own, a real ball, a Voit. My sporting life in Brooklyn had actually begun
title: ESSAY; The Brooklyn Game Had Its Own Beat

body: Reshaped and renamed by generations of developers and gentrifiers, the borders of New York City's neighborhoods are often hazy at best. Yesterday's Chinatown is today's east TriBeCa; a resident of Bedford-Stuyvesant may, after some real estate alchemy, morph into a citizen of Clinton Hill. These distinctions, with status, self-identity and resale
title: Amateur Mapmakers Redraw Boundaries, Working Online

body: IN her senior year at New York University, Rachel Bishop left dorm living behind. Since then, she has always paid under $1,000 a month -- sometimes well under -- for rent. Ms. Bishop, 25, started out as one of five roommates in a two-bedroom in Williamsburg, Brooklyn . Two roommates doubled up in each of the bedrooms, and the fifth had ''a little
title: THE HUNT; Have Guitars, Will Party

author: Meghan O'Rourke is the author of the poetry collections ''Once'' and ''Halflife.'' Her memoir, ''The Long Goodbye,'' was published last year.
body: WINTER JOURNAL By Paul Auster 230 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $26. Paul Auster was a novelist in Brooklyn before there were novelists in Brooklyn. (When I was growing up there in the 1980s, my father used to point him out to me as we did the grocery shopping in Park Slope -- this was a rare kind of sighting.) Back in those days, his novels -- the New
title: These Wild Solitudes

body: DURING New York Fashion Week , editors will seek standout microtrends like the long, tousled side braid of Alexander Wang's spring 2010 collection or the glowing sun-kissed complexion and feathery full brow that went with it. Those looks, and countless before and since, were created by Guido Palau, a hair stylist, and Diane Kendal, a makeup artist:
title: NEW YORK FASHION WEEK | SKIN DEEP; Two for the Runway

body: EACH fall brings New York a harvest of new restaurants, with most of the prime destinations in downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn. But this season the Upper East Side will rub its eyes and perk up at the sight of several exciting arrivals. Michael White will move in with a high-end project, Ristorante Morini. Laurent Tourondel will dish up steaks and
title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Chefs Try New Terrain, Like the Upper East Side

body: THIS morning, I grabbed a bowl from the cabinet, went outside and picked my breakfast of fresh figs . No, I'm not vacationing near the Mediterranean coast. Nor am I in California or the South. I'm at home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where the fig tree in my tiny garden is covered in ripening fruit. I've had the tree for 15 years, but when the
title: A GOOD APPETITE; Italy to Brooklyn, Fig by Fig

title: It's You, She Says, And at a Discount

Then you look at the wine list, dozens of choices all consistent with the
title: THE POUR; Should a Wine List Educate or Merely Flatter You?

body: OpeningAMY'S BREAD Amy Scherber, who started baking in a Hell's Kitchen storefront in 1992, keeps expanding the business. She opened a larger bread kitchen and cafe in Chelsea Market in 1996, added a cafe in Greenwich Village in 2005 and has now moved production from the market to 33,000 square feet of space in Long Island City, Queens. She calls
title: Off the Menu

body: SUMMER gridlock alert! The foreign tourists are here, moving languidly like amoebas on the sidewalks, clogging the subways and rounding the corners atop ubiquitous double-decker buses that rumble from Broadway to Brooklyn. You can't navigate in Midtown these days. Or in Central Park. Or on the Brooklyn Bridge. So why fight it? If it seems as though
title: Follow That Tourist

body: On a recent drizzly Saturday, the rain wasn't constant, but the flow into the canal was. Just below a grated metal bridge that connects Park Slope with Carroll Gardens, an almost-clear liquid could be seen streaming out of a cobblestone storm drain and into the Gowanus Canal. The liquid was rainwater mixed with raw sewage - paint thinner, last
title: CITY ROOM; Do-It-Yourself, as Applied to a Dirty Canal

body: 'Sarazad and the Monster-King' The 9-year-old heroine of E. J. C. Calvert's new play has more than one monster to deal with. The one in her dream has green skin, huge teeth and long claws and looks like a cross between a medieval gargoyle and a '50s sci-fi Martian. Those on the playground are rosy-cheeked and wear school uniforms and perpetual
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: For much of the past century, Brooklyn was the Rodney Dangerfield of boroughs, known for its blue-collar style, for its funny accent and, of course, for getting no respect. Then came the brownstone homesteaders and the bohemian pioneers. They turned lunch-bucket warrens in Park Slope, Dumbo and Williamsburg into glamorous destinations, drawing a
title: As Brooklyn Gentrifies, Some Neighborhoods Are Being Left Behind

body: Officers answering a call about a gas leak in a Bronx apartment building found a 5-year-old boy and his 4-month-old sister unconscious in an apartment that had dangerous levels of gas after the children's mother apparently turned on the oven and then cut her wrists, the police said Friday. Officers responding on Thursday night found the two
title: 2 Bronx Children Die After Their Mother Turns on Gas and Slits Her Wrists

body: Over the years, the property at 142 North Sixth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has gone through many changes. It has been a popular flea market, a condominium development with a bamboo garden, and, most recently, luxury rental apartments. Now, the 44-unit building has changed hands once again. Steiner NYC closed late last month on a $38 million
title: A Developer Makes a Shift From Offices in the Suburbs to City Housing

title: AT THE TABLE | BROOKLYN CRAB; Friends, Nostalgia and a Mountain of Seafood

Fake subway entrances, complete with
title: CITY ROOM; In 'Men in Black 3,' Court Street Is Dismissed

''We have families come in all the time on the weekends to walk, and if they're lucky, they get
title: Spare Times: For Children

title: BLOCK BY BLOCK | SMITH STREET, CARROLL GARDENS; Turn Left At the Roses

body: It has not been a particularly warm spring so far, but there have been some days when the students and teachers at a Brooklyn middle school might have better enjoyed their studies in an air-conditioned climate. After all, the elementary school that the school shares its building with is air-conditioned. But while the classrooms at New Horizons
title: SCHOOLBOOK; 2 Schools: A Have-Not And a Have

body: FLANKED by four campaign volunteers and a French television reporter, Corinne Narassiguin, a Socialist candidate in France's coming parliamentary elections, went canvassing in her would-be district one evening in May. But the doors she was knocking on were in the West Village. ''Bonjour, madame,'' Ms. Narassiguin said over a town house's intercom.
title: In New York, French Politics Is Local

body: AT a sunny street fair Sunday on the Lower East Side, students from the Ivy Smart Learning Center worked a tiny lemonade stand, jostling to be the one to add the lemon slices and pour the sugar. For the first time, New York City children were participating in Lemonade Day, a nationwide event sponsored by a Houston-based nonprofit group to encourage
title: Imagining a Smaller Drink for a Big, Thirsty City

body: DEVELOPERS in New York City have had a lot of success luring buyers to high-end apartments with the latest dazzling amenity. Heat reflexology flooring, anyone? But the feature still most likely to draw people is not something new and shiny but old and reliable: good bones. Many buyers re-entering the real estate market after years on the sidelines
title: Brooklyn's Gold Rush

body: The market for multifamily buildings in Brooklyn has been heating up over the last year. But the recent sale of 111 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg was stunning even in a hot market. The buyer, American Realty Advisors, paid $55.5 million, or more than $895,000 for each of 111 Kent's 62 apartments. The price paid per apartment is a record for such
title: SQUARE FEET; A Rental Market Surge in Brooklyn

body: OPENING AGATA & VALENTINA There is indeed an Agata -- Agata Musco, who owns the longtime Italian market on the Upper East Side with her husband, Joe Musco, and Louis Balducci. The Muscos' daughter, Valentina Musco Puleo, is also a partner in the store. Now, after 19 years, they are branching out. Their new store downtown, in rustic Sicilian style,
title: Off the Menu

body: Outsiders call it the street with little doors. That is, if they know it at all, because Dennet Place, a tiny lane near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is something of a secret. It can evade GPS, and even some people who have lived nearby for years have never heard of it. Those who do pass by wonder about the doors. Dennet houses have miniature
title: On an Inconspicuous Brooklyn Block, a Curious Nickname and Hobbit Doors

title: Off-the-Grid Living In Brooklyn

title: THE POUR; Red Before Labor Day: Summer's New Rules

body: IF one motto could be said to have guided all those responsible for the waves of development sustained by Downtown Brooklyn over the years, it might have been ''Think no small thoughts.'' title: LIVING IN | DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; To the Heights and the Slope, Add 'Downtown'

body: THREE months ago, when Wei Min Tan, a broker at Rutenberg Realty, negotiated a deal for a new $3 million three-bedroom condominium at the Aldyn on the Upper West Side, he was able to save his buyers $95,000 in transfer taxes and other costs, as well as to finagle a free storage space. But now, Mr. Tan said: ''I don't know if I could get the same
title: Condo Incentives

body: Around the turn of this century, the Miser knew a saxophonist in Brooklyn who would walk to rehearsals in Park Slope from his home in Carroll Gardens. He would head warily down Union Street, past dead, silent factories and the rusting remains of another era. On the Union Street Bridge he'd pause to hear, carried on the chemically compromised air
title: WEEKEND MISER; Free Events at Littlefield, and a PEN Reading in Carroll Gardens

title: THE APPRAISAL; As Rents Rise Across Brooklyn, She Stalks the Elusive $625 Apartment

title: Life on Her Own Terms For Beyoncé's Little Sister

title: A GOOD APPETITE; See You Later, Pizza, This Dough Is for Calzones

title: UPDATE; The Voters Speak: Yes to Bathrooms

title: The Make-Your-Own Schoolhouse

title: Relish: An M.V.P. Now Sidelined

title: SCHOOLBOOK; Number of Elementary School Students in Large Classes Has Tripled, a Councilman Says

We don't know if the charismatic sphinx Don Draper has married his secretary or pulled his flailing advertising firm out of the fire. But one prediction is a
title: Old-Fashioned or Newfangled, the Old-Fashioned Is Back

body: WHEN Frank Galeano was growing up on Union Street in the 1960s, Red Hook next door had so many abandoned buildings that he and his friends used them as ''clubhouses,'' running extension cords from nearby streetlights. In Red Hook today, houses are much harder to come by. Even fixer-uppers sell for nearly $1 million -- when available at all. Yet
title: LIVING IN | RED HOOK, BROOKLYN; Outlier Near the 'Center of the Universe'

body: LAURA MacCLEERY was four months pregnant when she parked herself on the couch and started an inventory of the chemicals in her Alexandria, Va., town house. First, Ms. MacCleery, 40, a lawyer and women's health advocate, collected 70 products in a pile: things like makeup, shampoo, detergents and sink cleaners. Then she typed the names of the
title: Is It Safe To Play Yet?

body: New varieties of hybrid tomatoes have been created in the time it has taken for one supermarket to rise in Brooklyn. Eight years ago, Whole Foods Market bought a 4.2-acre site on the corner of Third Street and Third Avenue, steps from the infamous Gowanus Canal. Since then, the chain has had a ribbon-cutting and removed the toxic waste on the
title: Decisive Vote Looms, Finally, For Whole Foods in Brooklyn

body: THE advantages of moving into a new building are many. But so are the potential pitfalls. For instance, having a home that, as Emily Stone put it, ''runs the risk of looking like Mickey Rourke's apartment in '9 1/2 Weeks,' '' a disturbingly chilly vision of modernity -- or, she added, a note of horror in her voice, ''The Jetsons.'' Ms. Stone, who
title: ON LOCATION; Taking the Chill Off Contemporary

body: Miriam and Christian Rengier, a German couple moving to New York, visited some private elementary schools in Manhattan last spring in search of a place for their son. They immediately noticed the absence of ethnic diversity, and the chauffeurs ferrying children to the door. And then, at one school, their guide showed them the cafeteria. ''The kids
title: Born Abroad, Well Off and Using Public Schools

body: It's easy to fall in love with a neighborhood in New York. And given the high cost of housing, it's common to realize that you can't afford the home you want in the neighborhood you love. So, what to do? Your first instinct may be to look a few stops away on the same subway line, trading Williamsburg for Bushwick, for instance. Or you might choose
title: You're Priced Out. Now What?
